SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Dist: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER SETTLEMENTS: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A SORT OF QUESTIONNAIRE TO THE PIONEER SETTLEMENTS IN SASKATCHEWAN

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences others may prove helpful. You may worry about leaving blank spaces, the best thing to do is to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions. This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1934, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experiences of the pioneer life there. If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Western Canadian Archives Questionnaire No. 1 entitled "Pioneer Days What Did You Do?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered it, and are willing to do so, please give a short reply.

Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires:
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Board,
University of Saskatchewan,
Canada, etc.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER KAFERLICHES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and places names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have it written, please say so. If you do not have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name ...........................................

2. Your address ...........................................

3. Date ...........................................

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) ...........................................

5. What was your father's name and occupation? ...........................................

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) ...........................................

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child" if I was in my teens", etc.)

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

My parents came to make a new beginning following a failure of the silver mines in Mexico.

10. How did you learn about the West? (through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

My parents heard glowing stories about how a fortune could be made by anyone who was not afraid of work and toil.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They thought we were insane and daily expectations to hear of our success.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With my family of eight, the oldest boy about 20.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Ship - then Train to Brandon

14. What incidents of the Journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Had been here four eighteen months, the last built a house twenty miles North of Brandon then returned to England to fetch us.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

20 miles North of Brandon

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I lived in the Butten district until 1929 when moved to Wapow for one year before moving to my present home in Dubuque.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Grew a small attending school.

After I came I lived on a farm near 1929.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

My attempt was more intense and daily expectation to hear of our success.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

With my family of eight, the oldest boy about 26.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Ship - then Train to Brandon

14. What incidents of the journey East do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

My father had been here for eighteen months, he knew built a house twenty miles north of Brandon and returned to England to find us.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

20 miles north of Brandon

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I lived near the eastern district until 1929 when moved to Neepawa for one year before moving to my present home in Burke.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I was a child attending school after I came I tried on a farm until 1929.
My sisters and I were stolen by the Indians and rescued by my father after the rebellion. The Indians were very unfriendly then, and I got separated from everyone. I always needed in the old country but got up and all before we could replace them. Then we moved north and bought land near 100 acres by land.
We all came together.

My sisters and I were stolen by the Russians and arranged by my mother after the abolition of the slave trade. We were very unfriendly to each other. I got separated from my family and ended up in the city. I met someone who got me a job offer. They could replace them with a team of men and women who arrived and built into acres by acres.

We had our own school in the early years, attended church regularly (twice weekly). We had our own school system based on a primary and a college education since then about 1990 (and a more modern one since the school). (The school in cities in population)

We didn't get much of anything, my sisters and I worked to earn our living in different jobs. We also worked at farms and did so many.
25. When was the first car used in the community? My husband used a car in 1912 for electioneering for the Conservative Party.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new terms appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days? My father went to town regularly to buy dry goods twice a year. Groceries came by mail about once a month in the summer.

30. On Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

About 1900 we began to order from Sherrard Brothers. We bought dry goods. About 1905 we ordered most of our dry goods from them. We have bought more and more from stores. Now standards and transportation have improved so much we do most of our shopping in the larger centers.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

About 1915 The Northern Electric Company.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

Yes.
25. When was the first car used in the community? My husband used a car in 1920 for a surveying party.

26. If you owned a car before 1924, when did you buy it? What makes?

27. Where was your traveling center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new terms appear-

29. How often did you shop in the early days? My father went to Calgary

30. When did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases by mail order and any changes since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When did you come to Saskatchewan the first time? Was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

One or two families of Welsh people moved to be closer to a P.C. church.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

700

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My husband was a member of the M. P. I. F. A. for 20 years and continued until 1929. He also served as the Secretary and Treasurer.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "firsts" to have or do something in the district mentioned here (driving dates wherever possible, such as owning the first automobile, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

My husband offered to be the first automobile owner.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts; post offices, villages, railway stations, areas, hills, etc.). Try to give (1) name and occupation of person registering place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in name since the first use was given date and reason for change.

The district, school and post office were all named after Cotton, a village in Bristol.
34. Did any people move away from your district or live to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

One in two families of these people moved to the slower to a P.O. church.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, please name it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My husband's career was as a teacher. He taught at the school for 20 years and continued until 1929. He also worked as a carpenter and a mechanic.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were interested in having or doing something in the district, mention it here. Bring dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, owning the first telephone, etc.)

My husband often had the first automobile.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, places named after people, etc.) Try to give (1) date and reason for change, (2) date and reason for change, (3) date and reason for change. Only names of new names above in (1), (2), or (3).

In district, school and post office were all named after Cotton, a village in Bristol.
